I felt cheated by this book. It started off with such promise and like a fat person with a box of chocolates in front of them, I couldn't wait to get wired in. At one point, I decided that this book was worthy of four stars. By the midway point though I was tired. Tired of the repetition. How many times does Jared Diamond have to refer to the fact that he believes the rise of food production to be the main determinant of success for a society, before he believes the reader might believe him. It just seemed like in this book, it was (at least) one time too many.

Diamond attempts to answer an age old question; what determines a society's position in relation to the others on Earth? The problem with the approach he uses is that it is just not robust enough to be worth sharing. My first problem is that just because things are the way they are, it doesn't mean they had to be. Unless otherwise convinced (and I would take some convincing) I just can't lend any weight to the idea that history is anything other than chaotic, influenced by countless factors, many of which we remain unaware. I just could not shirk off the impression that Diamond was coming up with a theory and then shoehorning facts into the theory to lend it credence. One example of this is the idea that societies rate of progress is determined largely by what way round the landmass they inhabit lies. He fails to mention The Alps, The Mediterranean, the Himalayas or the large temperature gradient between parts of Eastern Russia and Western Europe, as potential barriers to the diffusion of ideas between societies in Eurasia, instead choosing to blithely ignore them to fit his chosen hypothesis. To me that's a bit like saying that rather than teeth evolving to fit our diet, they evolved to improve our smile and hence give us more chance of attracting a mate. In other words, making up a theory to fit the facts and using the facts themselves as justification and choosing to ignore existing evidence.

To reinforce this impression in my mind, Diamond concludes by trying to justify his flimsy just-so explanations in a very patronising and unconvincing manner, suggesting that the main reason for disagreeing with them lies in a misunderstanding of the historical sciences and it's methods by the majority of people. He even goes as far as including the likes of evolutionary biology and astronomy in with history, suggesting that if we believe in the findings of the former disciplines, we should give more weight to the theories of the historical sciences (history). It is my belief that the findings within both astronomy and evolutionary biology are subjected to rigorous experimental testing, a belief which Diamond clearly does not hold. I could almost feel my faith and trust in Diamond as a scientist die inside me by the time I had turned the final page.

The whole thing is pretty flimsy. A few theories, which are either extroardinarily simple (geographical difference makes the difference in societies developments not the people) or flawed and/or lacking evidential support (the axis of the continent which a society inhabits makes a considerable impact upon it's development).

Finally the book is by and large, overwhelmingly dull. Diamond repeats himself like a broken record and wading through his prose feels at times like wading through thickened treacle on rubber stilts.

If you are looking for definitive answers to the central question of this book, answers that you feel assured are reasonably likely to be robust and accurate, this book does not provide them. It contains nuggets of trivia but that wasn't the reason I picked this off the bookshelf to read it and I think that would apply to most prospective readers.

“Outliers aren’t outliers…. they are [what they are] not because of some exceptional or heroic individual action on their part but because of whole series of circumstances, environments and cultural legacies.” – Malcolm Gladwell in an interview.

What is Gladwell essentially saying? He sums up the circumstantial, environmental and cultural reasons for being an outlier in the following ideas:

1. Luck has its role to play
2. Hard work and enough practice - 10000 hours – makes you good at almost anything
3. IQ doesn’t guarantee success. There exists a concept of IQ threshold. Psychological testing has its limitations
4. Being born at the right place, right time helps
5. Middle and higher class families typically provide better, nurturing home environments
6. Disadvantaged groups have access to fewer opportunities
7. If kids put more effort they could fetch better grades
8. Language affects how we organize information
9. Culture can shape personality
10. Racial discrimination has handicaps associated with it (epilogue)

Everything listed above (published in 2008) has either been out there in scientific and pop literature for decades, is scientifically tenuous (10000 hours) or is something that Captain Obvious would state. Gladwell has nothing new to offer, let alone adding an argument to enrich the nature-nurture debate. He ends up trying to convolute it with poorly supported assertions.

Part 1 broadly discusses about individuals, who indeed were exceptions. It was still pertinent to the title. In part 2, though, when he discusses the performance of Asians in mathematics or school kids taking California Assessment Battery – he is talking about averages and not outliers per se.
Different cultures prepare you for different things - cultural anthropologists established that in the 50s. Rather than comparing westerners and Asians on math performance, he should have addressed the existence of outliers within the oriental culture. That would have made more sense. He lost track in my opinion.

He makes sure that not one sentence is spared on confidence, motivation, temperament, personality dimensions, emotional regulation, self-esteem, self-efficacy, interests or learning/ perceptual styles! How did these factors play out in the lives of Gates, Joy or Jobs? Why are 80% of NBA players black? And why is not each one of them a LeBron, a Kobe or a Jordan?

He skipped judgment and decision making too. Decisions such as how and where to put effort into could be a critical success factor. I spent 220 minutes on this book. I could have used that time elsewhere. I could have slept or perhaps worked to accumulate those 10000hrs in one of my crafts.

Gladwell is not a psychologist; I should have known better. Drivel should have been expected.

The only outlier that doesn’t deserve to be one is this book itself. He should write a book on how “Outliers”, a below average text, managed to get a 4+ rating on Goodreads. I gave a star only because of the chapter on ice hockey and the 50 page babble dedicated to pilot communication – which, like so many in this book, was a feeble argument to make for a correlation between cultural legacy and outliers.

Finished. Done. Finally. This book was too easy to put down. I had such hopes. He writes in such a way that you feel completely absorbed in his narrative. It seems so interesting, until you realize, he just wrote about landscaping or concrete foundations for five pages and then I felt so betrayed that I'd put the book down. It was false advertising.

I wanted to read about how this psychopath wove himself into the 1893 World Fair in Chicago (dubbed the White City because all of the buildings built for the fair were painted white) but it never happened. Larson takes certain liberties and places H.H. Holmes (the devil in the title) at the fair with two women he murdered for a couple of days but it's the only time he ever connects the two stories.

He wrote an interesting history of the development of the fair and a descent portrayal of Holmes and his frightening existence, but how he decided to throw them together into one book and title it so that the two seem related is too much of a stretch. They both happened in Chicago in roughly the same time frame but it's like writing about the Washington D.C sniper murders like it had anything to do with building the World War II memorial on the National Mall. They just aren't related. Some happened in the same city during the same time...but some didn't and I don't think one really had anything to do with the other. Well, it's not quite as random as that...but almost.

I did learn a lot about architecture, and about the impact the fair had on America's history. That was fascinating. It brought about the design of the Ferris Wheel (although the first one was frightening - like 52 cars that could fit a hundred people in each one - no thanks), shredded wheat and other product icons. I probably would never check out a book on the 1893 Chicago World's Fair so if that was his intention...he succeeded. It's just too bad his talent for making even rose bed designs sound compelling couldn't produce the story he promised to tell.

This book was a total waste of time and I frankly cannot understand all the positive reviews.
The most important thing first: The book is full of errors. But not the-book-is-a-couple-of-years-old-and-we-didn't-know-better-errors. They are genuine totally-not-understandable-false-errors. Example:
"[the red giant star Betelgeuse is] fifty thousand light years away"
It's 640 ± 150 light years away.
Or this one:
"… 500,000,000,000 of them, rather more than the number of seconds contained in half a million years."
500,000,000,000 seconds equals ~15854,9 Years.
And there are more and (in my opinion) worse errors in the book. Some of them are listed here. Bryson tries to wow his readers by throwing big numbers at them which are blatantly wrong. No science book should contain errors of this kind. It's ridiculous. And the errors are only one thing. Half of the book is not about science itself, but about the scientists. And it's all the time "He did steal everything from his colleagues" or "He was mad" and so on. Bryson seems so desperate to entertain the readers that he gossips too much which is really annoying.

And now as I have finished this book I realize that I don't have learned anything that I couldn't have learned through a quick google search.

column12: As a historian I read this book with rising horror and revulsion at the wholly unethical way Rebecca Skloot pursued the Lacks family after they had asked her not to call them anymore. At the point where you're quoting the Lacks children saying they felt they had no choice but to talk to Skloot because she wouldn't stop calling them, this woman became no better than a tabloid journalist. It seems as though she has created an "us and them" in her mind between her harassment of the Lacks family and that of other journalists who did the same thing. She mentions late in the book that while she was speaking with Henrietta's cousins in Virginia over the course of ten months since Deborah told her she was unwilling to speak to hee anymore, she was calling her "every few days". This is totally unethical and goes against everything historians are taught about approaching subjects for research, no matter the public interest in what they might have to say. I'm sorry I spent money on this book since she didn't give a cent to the Lacks family, and without their generosity and patience and willingness to share their traumatic family history, she wouldn't have had a story in the first place.
column15:
Dr. Sacks is a neurologist who wants to be a philosopher. Unfortunately for us readers, he did not want to be a writer. This makes for frustrating reading and a violation of the cardinal rule of writing: know your audience. If you are also a neurologist who wants to be a philosopher and you have old fashioned ethics, then this is your book! If, like most people, you are not, then prepare for medical jargon coupled with esoteric allusions embedded in stories that ramble on and on until they abruptly end.

Dr. Sacks will examine how the human spirit is affected by the medical condition at hand, and this is fascinating at first. Amnesia and other rare psychological disorders have been milked fantastically by Hollywood, so simply telling the true version would make for a compelling read. Unfortunately, Dr. Sacks tries to get at the human spirit of the patient, and this leads to pulling in Kant, Hume ("Humean being" was easily my favorite unintended pun in the book), Wittgenstein and others as a springboard for lengthy ramblings about the nature of humanity and what makes us human. These ramblings often trail off into a series of questions for the reader, not unlike a sophomore philosophy essay.

Worse yet, multiple stories lack an ending. For instance, we only hear about the one night of a man who suddenly believes that his left leg is not his own. Fascinating story, but we don't know if he snaps out of it the next day or saws it off later that night! The story just ends. Often times the ending is vague and consists of the person doing alright all things considered.

Multiple times Dr. Sacks will reference specific works of fiction or his own jargon ("incontinent nostalgia" comes up many times before the chapter that defines it) and how this person is just like a character or situation in "Funes the Memorious" by Borges, or "The Door in the Wall" by HG Welles or the L-Dopa patients in Dr. Sack's other book. These stories are never summarized, so you will want an encyclopedia handy, otherwise you'll be missing out. The most frustrating instance of this is the entirety of chapter 9, which discusses two interpretations of a presidential speech without ever telling us anything about the speech!

However, there is one thing that kept me reading for as long as I did: the glimpse into the mind of old doctor ethics. This is a time when, "Give it to me straight, Doc." was necessary, as Dr. Sacks often does not tell the patient what is wrong. In the title story, when asked by the Man who Mistook his Wife for a Hat, "What's wrong with me?", Dr. Sacks dodges the question! We also get to see the archaic system of care for the mentally handicapped, as we meet a woman who has literally never done anything for herself because of her Parkinson's and a caretaker who flatly says, "He's an idiot. Don't even ask him. [...] They say he's 'autistic', but he is just an idiot."

Caveat lector!

column11:
Thank god I don't believe in god because I am going to commit blasphemy.

Elie Wiesel overdoes it. Wait, no, I am not saying he didn't suffer. Not that part. Elie Wiesel overdoes the writing. As more competent people than me have pointed out, this is a book which has been culled down from a 800+ page historical fiction to a barely 100+ testimonial along its' journey of various translations. I really think a lot of the nuance has been lost in the process. The page on this on Wikipedia has this bit

Seidman argues that the Yiddish version was for Jewish readers, who wanted to hear about revenge, but the anger was removed for the largely Christian readership of the French translation. In the Yiddish edition, for example, when Buchenwald was liberated: "Early the next day Jewish boys ran off to Weimar to steal clothing and potatoes. And to rape German shiksas [un tsu fargvaldikn daytshe shikses]." In the 1958 French and 1960 English editions, this became: "On the following morning, some of the young men went to Weimar to get some potatoes and clothes—and to sleep with girls [coucher avec des filles]. But of revenge, not a sign."


This is important because the entire tone has been flipped. Maybe this is a singular instance but this implies so much. I won't say whitewash but I really think the years on Wiesel has led to him making this a legend, this literary tale of what really was human people doing monstrous things in inhumane environments. People who follow me will know this quote from Iris Chang

"Civilisation is paper-thin."

Wiesel in Night tries often too hard to elicit emotions. I feel very bad for saying this but he does. He writes these over the top dramatic sentences which just do not land. THEY DON'T LAND. This is my personal opinion, that instead he could have just let the moment linger and the horror set in. The dramatics only draws us away. My favourite parts of the book are when I hear other characters talk or do things. Too often we are just plopped down and made to hear what Wiesel thought about it and he doesn't really offer useful insight, he just tries to flap his wings for effect and all it does is lend what may be a true non-fictional account, the air of a fairy-tale because he smooths over characters, reduces them to situations and his perspective. In a way, he actively smothers the characters. Franek the foreman(who is kind normally but greedy and looking out for himself more than anything else) is a genuinely interesting character but all we get to know of him is through Eisel's eyes and his assumptions about him. He is reduced to his two incidents with the author. Maybe I ask too much, how can a man tell you about other real people whom he never got to know.

But look, Iris Chang in her book, offers a captivating duality of Matsui Iwane, the general of the Rape of Nanking. While she says that he is guilty and deserved death, she also doesn't fail to highlight that some onlookers say he was genuinely distressed by the massacre but just didn't act.

What ends up here is that Elie turns a horrific true story into a parading of his literary writing skills which aren't nearly as good as he thinks them to be. It reduces the narrative and I can't help but imagine how much better this would have been if he had adapted a more strict approach to either side. He could have written a formal account which would be more terrifying just for stating the facts as it happened and letting you figure out how men can act like that. Or he could have written a fictional account, with broader characterisation which would have brought true humanity and suffering to the table. In his attempt to "glorify" his suffering and stretch it pompously to losing faith in god(which look if done right would have been fucking amazing), he only destroys the horrific reality of the situation and lends fact to fiction instead of the other way.
column12:
This book represents, to me, much of what is wrong is pop non-fiction. The author was far too present throughout the entire book, and the book itself is a much more about her and her obsession with Henrietta Lacks than it is about anything else. White guilt and righteous indignation were two main themes pervading much of the writing. The narrative was all over the place, and at the end of the book, I couldn't tell why it had been written. To educate about inequalities of health care? (not really, the issue was never actually discussed in anything but a hyper-emotional way) To honor Henrietta Lacks? (not really--her person and character disappears after a few chapters) To explain what HeLa cells are for? (again, not really--it was discussed, but not with any sense of purpose, more just a rambling set of facts) To just review the history of the cells and Henrietta's family in a wandering journey highlighted by chapters that were unconnected to one another without a broad theme? Possibly.

This sentence really illustrates everything that is wrong with this book: "Though the judge in the John Moore case said patients must be told if their tissues have commercial potential, there was no law enacted to enforce that ruling, so it remains only case law."

What the HELL is she talking about? Case law IS law! For example, all law regarding the meaning of the fourth amendment (searches and seizures) is case law. Terry stops and frisks? Case law. Miranda warnings? Case law. Case law IS ENFORCEABLE LAW. That's why it's enforced. All the time. If this author managed to miss that fact, what else is wrong? I could spot places in the book where she was just wrong about law, or places where her statements amounted to inaccuracies. But I don't know anything about science--so I could not spot where she was wrong there. What the hell was going on in this book? Who edited it?

And, also, as a personal note to Skloot: The John Moore case is not just law, it's a really important seminal case. So important that they make all law students read the damn case in their first year of law school. It's enforceable. Legislators don't need to enact another law to enforce it.
column15:
Many many years ago while a lowly medical student, I read The Island of the Colour-blind and Cycad Island and came away a little underwhelmed. A grand desire to avoid any form of medical writing since has kept me away from the rest of his catalogue but with his recent death I decided to pick up one of his more famous titles.

I struggled. I think part of the issue is the intervening 30 years since publication. He's firmly routed in a somewhat outmoded form of neurology and it shows (plus he seems to love Freud). Ideas and knowledge have moved on and it makes it hard to appreciate read with modern understanding. He's also clearly got some idols and almost every anecdote is linked to them in some way without him really explaining their significance (aside from a brief mention in the bibliography).

His thoughts and interpretations comprise an odd mix of neurology, psychiatry and quasi-mysticism with a little sociology, philosophy and bullshitting thrown into the mix. There's definitely some ego at play here. I generally didn't accept his interpretations or like the style as a result and agree that his flowery repetitive prose can get a little muddling at times.

I had no issue with the terminology though I'm not sure the lay public would necessarily find it that easy to pick up without a glossary or some Wikipedia work. I'm not entirely sure which audience he's writing for.

If you throw in some outdated and insulting terminology, some terribly written reconstructed dialogue and a disjointed structure, it just didn't work for me.

He was clearly an intelligent guy who deeply cared about his patients and put a huge amount of thought into the inner workings of the mind. He just isn't for me.

The only good thing I can say about this book is that it serves as a one stop collection of references to more intelligent analysis of the topic of introversion. The book itself  brings nothing to the table. Worse than that, by cherry picking data to support her generalizations, she does introverts a huge disservice. She actually manages to make introverts sound like weaklings which I feel insulted by. Her implication that introverts are superior, sensitive beings who absorb every negative slight to slowly destroy their psyche is just ridiculous. 

In Chapter 11, she gives ‘insights’ for parenting introverts - Don't tell your kid she's shy, be a role model by greeting strangers in a calm gentle way, don't pick over-aggressive kids as playmates, let your child know gently that tugging at your pant legs is not okay, instead let him know speaking up quietly is better to get attention. Three simple rules will help: Smile, stand up straight and make eye contact? - What the bloody hell? In the real world, all that is just obvious basics of good parenting! She actually says “make sure you're not imposing your own dreams on your kid” Well, no shit!
 
Chapter 8 is probably her least balanced chapter. She discusses how studious the Cupertino Asians are and is positively salivating about how great they are. Reading this chapter, one would think that all Asian kids are born studious introverts and sadly have to make radical adjustment when they face the terrible extroverted American life. Presumably, the only extroverted Asians she met were the ones that were sadly changing their core beings to fit into American society! There’s no discussion of the pressures faced by the kids to succeed at the expense of exploring other aspects of life.
 
I wish I had read the conclusion chapter first which basically sums up the book. From her bullet points on the insights she felt she had provided, I’d have been able to see she had nothing more than already well known ideas and I’d have skipped this one.
 
Save yourself the trouble and copy down her references to read instead.

column16:
I'm so angry that this book has a high rating and is considered the top Columbine book. It's filled with so many lies! I read chapter two while scoffing, incredulously. The author writes about Eric Harris "Dates were not a problem. Eric was a brain, but an uncommon subcategory: cool brain. He smoked, he drank, he dated. He got invited to parties... And he got chicks. Lots and lots of chicks. On the ultimate high school scorecard, Eric outscored much of the football team. He was a little charmer". What in the actual fuck? First off, what a gross way to write. What grown man refers to high school girls as chicks? Yuck. And the lies! Eric did not get with many girls, and he most likely died a virgin. He was rejected by most of the girls he approached. It's obvious that the author is trying to paint a picture of Eric that just isn't true. He wasn't cool by Columbine's standards. Eric was at the very bottom of the school's hierarchy. Even bullied by freshmen when he was a senior. The author says that Eric is a psychopath and that bullying wasn't a cause for the shootings.

From Eric's diary:

November 12, 1998
Everyone is always making fun of me because of how I look, how fucking weak I am and shit, well I will get you all back: ultimate fucking revenge here. you people could have shown more respect, treated me better, asked for knowledge or guidance more, treated me more like a senior and maybe I wouldn't have been as ready to tear your fucking heads off. Then again, I have always hated how I looked, I make fun of people who look like me, sometimes without even thinking sometimes just because I want to rip on myself. That's where a lot of my hate grows from. The fact that I have practically no self esteem, especially concerning girls and looks and such. therefore people make fun of me .. constantly..therefore I get no respect and therefore I get fucking PISSED.

November 17, 1998
Whatever I do, people make fun of me, and sometimes directly to my face. I'll get revenge soon enough.

And from his final entry on April 3, 1999
I hate you people for leaving me out of so many fun things. And no don't fucking say, "well thats your fault" because it isn't, you people had my phone #, and I asked and all, but no. no no dont let the weird looking Eric KID come along, ohh fucking nooo.

Do these sound like the inner feelings of a cool, charming kid? Or do they sound like the words from a kid who's desperate to fit in and be accepted?

There are various reports from the boys' peers regarding just how bad the bullying was including jocks throwing skittles and other various food at them in the cafeteria. During one incident, Eric and Dylan were surrounded by jocks who threw ketchup covered tampons at them. Another incident saw fecal matter being thrown at them. They were constantly called "faggots" and a female student, amongst her group of girlfriends asked the boys when they were getting married. Eric and Dylan had to walk with their heads down or risk being tossed against a locker and called a "fag". They say Eric had it worst of all because he was small in stature. He also had an indent in his sternum, so he never took his shirt of during gym class, giving the jocks even more reason to bully him. He was also extremely introverted and shy, and he dressed differently. You can imagine how all this stuff would make him an easy picking for the bullies. His coworkers at Blackjack say that Eric complained he was being bullied. They say that no one ever gave Eric a chance.

Bullying is the fucking worst. I hate how it's downplayed in this book. How dare the author skirt such a vitally important issue. These boys didn't grow up hurting animals and looking for every opportunity to hurt others. If they were accepted by their peers and weren't bullied, the Columbine massacre would not have happened.

The author's confirmation bias is obvious, and he used small pieces of evidence and sometimes outright lies to support it. There are plenty of other lies and things that annoy me about this book, but I would have to write my own book to explain them.

column20: To actually put into words what I thought about this book would take a very long time and possibly more characters than I am allotted by goodreads. Suffice it to say that Rachel Carson wrote an essay, not a book. As a book, it is incessantly repetitive and generally dull, but as an essay it is well-sourced and addresses many of the issues the author saw with insecticide use. There are many, many, MANY times that the author grasps at a "perfect world" kind of ideal, without accounting for the need for jobs and a level of specific yield for farmers to profit in the first place. Carson demonizes anyone who doesn't agree with her, and bestows sainthood upon anyone that does agree with her, even if it is the same group! This book is absolutely littered with logical fallacy and I couldn't wait until it finally ended. The absolute last chapter of the book is where the vast majority of her solutions to these problems can be found, but many of those solutions have just as many issues when taken and put into a biome as insecticide chemicals do. All in all, I'm glad that we saved Bald Eagles, Peregrine Falcons, and California Condors because of the scare tactics that were used in this book, but I do not agree with the blatant skewing of reality that Carson tries to pass off as fact, and the worldwide ban of DDT causing rampant death in countries (esp. in Africa) that need vector control. Individual human life is worth more than our genetics (something Carson specifically doesn't agree with) and individual human life is worth more than ecology. Yes, it is important for us to innovate products that are better for the environment if we can, but this is generally a gradual process. It is also important that production is not stifled by using new products, and that new products don't bring more harm then good, as Carson should have wanted. In the modern version of ecology, we are encouraged to "go green" but in so doing we encourage the cobalt mining that results in the deaths of so many African children that it is abhorrent that this is still a thing. Human life (and it seems necessary to distinguish this, AFRICAN LIFE) is more important than the lives of animals! It's ridiculous! If they are African, who cares if they die, if we get to see more birds in our country... AKA the new form of liberal racism.
column21:
I have finally finished this unbearable book of platitudes. "Figure out what you are meant to contribute to the world and make sure you contribute it," she writes. "Love is essential; gregariousness is optional." And a good thing, too. "Spend your free time the way you like, not the way you think you're supposed to." If lines like this make you, like me, want to vomit, then you may want to reconsider spending your free time finishing this book like you think you're supposed to.

This book had little interesting to say about introversion that could not be captured in a 60-second Google search. It seemed to me that the book's primary purpose was, in fact, to flatter introverts -- the book's likely audience -- by telling them that they are not alone and that they, too, could contribute Value to the world. One of the author's favorite gambits, for example, is to reveal that some of history's greatest and most successful personages -- Mahatma Gandhi! Rosa Parks! Warren Buffett! Eleanor Roosevelt! -- were introverts (ZOMG! We introverts are awesome, hooray, lulz!). "None of this is to denigrate those who forget ahead quickly, or to blindly glorify the reflective and careful," the author hastens to explain. Except that it is, wink wink.

She spends most of the book telling introverts what we already know about ourselves: that we are the way we are. (See, e.g., anectodal examples of introverts acting introverted, ad nauseum! And it's OKAY! Introversion is perfectly normal, guys! We're just mizunderst00d by those unfeeling, unthinking extroverts.)

To be sure, the author offers some potentially useful advice for parents of introverts, and for teachers and managers (Be mindful that there are introverts in the world. Don't just structure the world around extroverts! 'kay, thanks!). But the main thrust of the book is Hooray Introverts!, Introverts Are Cool!, If You're An Introvert and Want to Hear All About How You Are Just As Awesome As Everyone Else Please Buy My Book!

Consider this introvert utterly bored.
column24:
WHY DID YOU CHOOSE TO READ THIS BOOK?

I’ve owned two copies of this book since the mid-eighties. It was on the list of required books for a couple of courses I took in college, yet I never even thumbed through either copy. So, since I’m one who always seeks to get her money’s worth, I felt it was high time to cash in.

WHAT DID YOU LIKE ABOUT THIS BOOK?

I appreciated this book’s commitment to no frills.

WHAT DID YOU NOT LIKE ABOUT THIS BOOK?

It’s dated; thus, gender-inclusive language is not employed, and there were a couple of cases of prescriptive snobbery that almost convinced me to stop reading the book. I'm committed to the rules of language in that it serves to facilitate communication, but it serves us best when it is reasonably dynamic.

I certainly was astonished when I read the following argument for the preservation of the male pronoun as the standard representation of all people.
No one need fear to use he if common sense supports it. The furor recently raised about he would be more impressive if there were a handy substitute for the word. Unfortunately, there isn’t—or, at least, no one has come up with one yet. If you think she is a handy substitute for he, try it and see what happens.

We’ve done just fine including the female gender as standard language since 1979, which was when this version of The Elements of Style was published. Furthermore, we are now in the midst of including transgender language. I’m fully in support of introducing a new set of pronouns to distinguish between cis-gender and transgender individuals. I’m not thrilled about using "they" in the singular though and hope "ver" and "xem" will be incorporated. My argument is why corrupt standard usage when you can expand the language instead? After all, it’s very exciting to create a new set of pronouns, especially since it doesn’t happen very often at all.

column16:
Dave Cullen weaves a well-researched and thoughtfully organized story together, covering the shooting, the planning, and the legal and emotional aftermath. Unfortunately, he does this at the expense of the truth.

Halfway through the book, I was planning on giving it 4/5 maybe 5/5. At this time, however, I started a cursory search online for other information about Columbine. On Reddit, r/columbine almost universally and vocally spews their distrust of Cullen's narrative. On Amazon, the mother of Brooks Brown (former friend of the killers) gives this book a 1/5 and details how inaccurate it is.

Most of the other criticisms of this book regard Cullen's attempt to craft his own narrative of the events, portraying Eric as a student motivated by psychopathy and hate and Dylan as a depressed and romantic teen who was dragged into the shooting by Eric. Cullen goes against all the evidence to assert that bullying/feeling like an outlier had nothing to do with the shooting.

Quickly after continuing the second half of the book, I discovered these criticisms to be spot on. Essentially, Cullen decided - for some reason that remains to be seen - to craft a contrarian narrative that disagreed with parents, students, witnesses, and - especially - Dylan and Eric. They write for weeks on end that they are motivated by revenge and film numerous videos where they list specific students by name.

Cullen is so clearly and bafflingly biased. There's even a sentence where he claims that "love is the most common word in Dylan's journal entries. Eric spewed hate in his."

Cullen's account of the events conflicts with the numerous other books published on this subject. I like a story just as much as the next guy, I just wish it was the right one.

column20:
I will start by saying that some good came out of this book: thanks to her and people like Al Gore, the EPA was created, the FDA inspects more produce and requires more science before allowing pesticides into the market, and the USDA is also more involved. That said, it's hard to even classify this book as science. It's every anti science, anti corporate, anti modern breakthrough, and woo peddler's bible.
She starts off by trying to claim that the only disease carrying insects that exist are in areas of cramped living areas in cities, where cleanliness, sanitation, and poverty exist. Even in the early 1900s through the mid 1950s, this wasn't true. Certainly, there were more pathogen carrying insects, but such conditions do not need to exist for them to be a threat.
Then she actually tried to claim that farmers never had insect problems until they began single crop and farming for more than just a few families. Maybe she should have stuck to marine biology. Farming and anthropological studies have shown that insects have ALWAYS been a problem.
She continued to compare the use of pesticides to radiation fallout as a scare tactic. She cited multiple discredited researchers--many of whom were even discredited at the time of publication.
I especially took issue with the three examples of leukemia and DDT (not that there aren't problems with the insecticide itself), but leukemia doesn't develop and kill within hours or days. Ever.
According to her, the entire population will either be sterile, or develop some form of cancer. Just the fact that she alluded to the use of pesticides and "retardation" in addition to "being mongoloid" is infuriating. The idea came from Dr. H. J. Muller's work with Xrays and fruit flies. She went on to explain that people born with XXY, XXX, or XO chromosomes are also the result of pesticide exposure. (Or radiation.) Just about any illness and/or defect can be blamed on it.
My favorite line of the whole book? "There is no 'safe' dose of a carcinogen." Alcohol is a carcinogen. The sun is a carcinogen. Thousands of things we come into contact with daily are carcinogens.
It's easy to be afraid of chemicals, but just as easy to learn basic science.
column21:
From the start I was very frustrated with the "us" (introverts) versus "them" (extroverts) tone that carries throughout the book. This is a complex characterization; different people fit into different categories based on circumstances and situations. Putting everyone into only two categories oversimplifies human behavior.

The author states American society is dominated by extroverts; introverts are either pushed to the sidelines or forced to become extroverts. Yet the only examples she presents to support this statement are Harvard Business School and, to a lesser extent, salesmen. Neither of these examples are even somewhat representative of American society. Most of the author's examples of introverts seemed to argue against an extrovert dominated society.

The author only mentions the fields of law and psychology. Why wasn't there more research or discussion about stereotypical introvert fields like engineering, mathematics, or research science? I have a hard time understanding how the author struggled to make a connection between race but didn't dive into the segregation of professional fields in our own culture.

The Asian argument was interesting but poorly developed. How do Indian cultures differ? I would have been interested in more development of Asian business culture. Where is the line between cultural differences and personality type differences? (I used to work for an engineering firm in Taiwan; of all the challenges we faced, I never felt is was due to different personality types).

Another frustrating theme that carried throughout was one third to one half of society are introverts. Yet, the author narrated as if introverts are a significant minority, a uncommon occurrence. Where are all these extroverts that dominate our culture? I don't know any, maybe I have subconsciously built up a shield and only surround myself with the introvert minority.

One star may seem harsh, but this was a very frustrating book for me to get through.

Don't read it! Everything this book says about grammar - which is a large portion of what its about - is wrong. Strunk and White believed objectively untrue myths that make anyone who has actually studied grammar cringe (some of these were added in later editions, others are baked into the original): "you can't end a sentence with a preposition,"and "don't split infinitives." Strunk doesn't understand pronoun case (He vs Him, I vs me, ect.) and his section on why you should never use passive voice just shows that he doesn't even know what passive voice is. If you're looking at this book because some college professor or writer recommended, rest easy knowing that many of the people who swear by this book probably haven't read it.
As to the parts that aren't grammar, it's mostly things that sound like sage advice until you think about for a second and realize it's useless, like "do not overwrite" or "be clear." There is also a bizarre section that tells the reader not to use adjectives or adverbs. Obviously, the authors fail completely to follow their own advice.

column1:
I guessed when I read the introduction of this book that I might not like certain aspects of this telling. Oh how right I was!

This book is a quick read--granted, I'm not finished yet (only about 1/4) (later note: finished it), but I didn't spend much time reading it either. The writing is smooth and it held my interest. It is really readable. It did try too hard at times, for example with the constant foreshadowing, and the veracity/objectivity quotient could have been more, well, present. But the problem is not with the writing, per se.

I suppose it comes down to my objections about sensationalizing violence against women. Larson is constantly uses foreshadow to try and pique your interest. I found it unsettling that Larson kept trying to titillate me about grisly murders of young women. Larson goes out of his way to tell you how beautiful and voluptuous and they all are, how "rapturous" their bodies. I'm assuming he means rapturous for the straight, Western, current mainstream male gaze, because we really don't know anything about these women and how they relate to their own bodies. And they're so "young," too--a word that can be applied as reasonably to a person of 5 years old as of 35. And really, what does it matter their age or what they looked like? How does it even make a difference? What is he trying to say? That their beauty, large bosoms, or age were the "cause" or "reason" for their deaths? After all, Larson starts this book out with an epigraph from the murderer attesting that he was born to kill, he just couldn't help it--even though his deliberations, planning, and actions in daily life point to the contrary. Or is Larson's meaning less victim-blaming and more of a slasher flick gore porn tactic: "See this nubile and attractive woman...now see her being tortured, hacked to pieces, and incinerated!!"? Is it that Larson only expects you to care about a victim that is conventionally attractive? Either way, I don't appreciate it.

I absolutely understand that these murders happened and that they are horrific. That's why I find it distasteful to put so much focus on Holmes and what he did and what he thought and how people interacted with him and what his childhood was like; and conversely, when the focus on the victims, to talk only about their appearance. Each of those victims had childhoods and plans and people they interacted with too. I can tolerate reading about a large amount of physical violence without finding it distasteful; many books that I find profound, moving, and important have very violent parts. Sometimes the violence is part of what makes a book important, as in books about wars and genocide. But in what I read of the book, the victims are portrayed as completely one dimensional, characterized solely as young and beautiful: that is also a violent act, albeit more subtle.

There were other instances of the same sort of weird, subtle hostility towards women. For instance, this statement, thrown in when relating a dinner party meeting for the fair's architects: "There was not a woman in sight." In context this is a complete non sequitur. It is a meeting of architects designing the fair; this is the 1890s: there are no women architects. Why would a woman be there? Indeed the only time Larson mentioned women in this story line prior to this was once to say Burnham and Root got married, and second to say "By 1886, he and Margaret were the parents of five children." It's not like Burnham's story line is teeming with females. Why draw attention to it now? Just to point out the fact that women do not participate in anything important, to remind us that they only exist to be slaughtered? Is that why? Is there some other reason? I am honestly curious and it is driving me crazy wondering what compelled him to insert that sentence in that place. [Update: I am happy to report that I was wrong about there being no female architects: there was ONE, who arrived on the scene much later, but I am unhappy to report that she was not given much importance in the book, and her little piece ends by being carted off to an insane asylum...so...]

There is a part in the book where Larson talks about all the disappearances in Chicago. He says, "The women were presumed to have been ravished." Ravished, yes--that's a nice euphemism for "raped & murdered," isn't it? Ravish, a word my dictionary defines with "(often be ravished) fill (someone) with intense delight; enrapture." That the word refers to both rape and delight is not a mistake. And that Larson used this word is not a mistake either. And that is why I put down the book and wrote this review.

After having written this and let it sit for a few hours, I think one of the reasons I'm so fed up is that it's the second book nonfiction book I've read in two days that trivializes rape and violence against women. Yesterday's was memoir-ish, but this one...should have been more objective. He did so much ~research~ and blah blah blah. Many reviewers make the point that the stories of the two main men are not connected at all. So why choose Holmes? Why not, as one reviewer suggested, choose to tell the story a brothel madam's life, or a Zulu person who was at the fair? Or one of the new young working women, or one of the guys working at the Union Stock Yard, or a grip-car operator? You could easily tell the story of Gilded Age Chicago through them. But that, of course, would not be nearly so ~!~OMG~!~ riveting or sensational. So he makes the choice to use women's brutalized bodies to make his book a bestseller.

So those are some thoughts I have had part way through. I'm going to keep reading but I predict that I'm going to leave this book at 1 star because trivializing violence against women really bothers me. The rest of the book is actually quite enjoyable but this is a dealbreaker for me when it comes to rating a book.

Diamond sets out to explain how and why is it that certain societies developed; why some never moved past being "hunter-gathers," whilst others developed into Empires with complex organisational structures, a mercantile class ect ect. Diamond believes that the answer is not that there is an innate difference in the intelligence of individuals but rather is due to differences in the availability of desirable 'Real Estate.' That is differences in "the continents’ different areas, axes, and suites of wild plant and animal species."

Unfortunately this is book is an example of a novel completely loosing me in the final stages of my reading experience. Without the 2017 Afterword entitled 'Rich and Poor Countries in Light of Guns, Germs and Steel,' I would have still believed that Guns, Germs and Steel ultimately presented a flawed answer to the question posed by Diamond, as any attempt by an author who was attempting to distill 13 000 years of human development into a 400 page book would be.

Whilst Diamond maintains throughout his endeavour he has set out to dispel racist stereotypes that have persisted (and propagated by colonial powers), his single minded determination to see the development of human civilisation through the lens of a single historical theory, geographical determinism, combined with Diamond's insistence that Eurasian nations "just got lucky" ends up absolving colonial powers for their direct involvement in shaping the trajectory of modern African, South American and the Middle Eastern nations and Indigenous societies around the world. For example, in the 2017 Afterword Diamond insists that all South Korea needed to advance into a modern and wealthy nation and build on its historical "advantages" was " only independence , military security and American foreign-aid assistance." His statement betrays a key blind spot in his analysis. The word 'imperialism' never even appears in the book. In ignoring economics, religion, culture and the complex way class and political division was utilised by Empires throughout history to exploit societies and use the profits to aid their own development, Diamond's history ignores a large part of the story of human development.

column17: Tom O'Neil's Chaos reveals that Bugliosi's version of events of the Manson Family murders is seriously dubious if not outright fabrications. column20:
This book has been responsible for more lies and death than any other book in human history, with the exception of 'The Communist Manifesto' and 'Mein Kampf'. Rachel Carson's crusade against synthetic chemicals, on the grounds that they caused cancer at a much higher rate than naturally-occurring chemicals (an unproven claim), led to the banning of the use of DDT against malaria-carrying mosquitoes in Africa. At the time, African countries were in the process of eliminating malaria from the continent. The consequence? Malaria was never eliminated. In fact, it returned with a vengeance and in the intervening decades tens of millions of Africans have died because of this ban on DDT.

Carson's 'scientific' claims have proven to be almost entirely false and/or gross exaggerations of the evidence. She claimed authority as a scientist, but wrote as an ideologue. This abject failure of this books major claims, combined with the millions of deaths due to her irresponsible rhetoric, is an object lesson on how scientists, when they push ideological agendas, ruin lives.
column21:
I found this book to be incredibly biased and dull, and I'm surprised that it is so highly rated with such great reviews. For someone who has studied and is well versed in the widely accepted Jung theories of introversion and extroversion, I found the author's take on introverted and extroverted qualities to be incredibly generalized.

The author made statement such as "extroverts, in other words, are characterized by their tendency to seek rewards, from top dog status to sexual highs to cold cash" and "this theory of extroversion is still young, and it is not absolute... it suggests that when it comes time to make group decisions, extroverts would do well to listen to introverts, especially when they see problems ahead."

I personally have known impulsive, pleasure-seeking introverts and thoughtful, problem-solving extroverts. These bold and generalized statements do nothing to help people understand each other's preferences or work more effectively together, rather they imply that one type is better than the other and encourage an "us versus them" mentality.

The author went back and forth between detailed dull scientific concepts, practical situational examples, and then over-generalized statements summarizing the two. The book definitely felt a bit self-serving, as the author makes it clear that she considers herself an introvert who has struggled in an "extroverted world".

I'm not saying that the author didn't make any good points or that there wasn't any truth to some of the concepts she put forward, but to be honest, the continued bias throughout the book made the author lose some credibility with me. There are so many great books out there about personality and introversion/extroversion that are balanced and put forth tips and suggestions for interacting with people who are different from us, that it's disappointing to see this book getting so much attention.
column24:
It's not exactly a guide to grammar, and not really a guide to style. It's not terribly useful either.

The grammar section focuses on a few complex constructions described using jargon that is not really explained. Some elements of grammar presented as rules are in fact merely opinions of the authors and disagree with historical literary usage (as pointed out by GK Pullam in his wonderful article, '50 Years of Stupid Grammar Advice'). This includes the singularly offensive "rule" that unless the subject is explicitly female, the third person singular must always be masculine (for example, 'when a scientist goes to work, he usually ...'). There is some vague advice about composition, and finally there is a list of commonly misused words. I can't see how this book could be useful to anyone.
